page.title: 11RANBY 'CAMP'
page.content: The site of Ranby Prison, locally known as Ranby 'Camp', has been in official use since the First World War, when it was the location of the East Retford Airfield. It was used as a training airfield by the Royal Flying Corps. It was mostly engaged in night flying. No. 187 Squadron was formed on April 1st 1918, under the command of Major T.H.Irons. The aircraft flown were BE2c's, Sopwith Pups and Camels, De Havilland 6's and AVRO 504k's. The squadron was disbanded on May 1 1919. In the inter-war years the airfield was used for flying displays, but during the Second World War it was used by the Army as a primary training centre. In 1950 the camp became the base of the 19th Tank Transporter Squadron and remained so until the summer of 1969.
